thread.section_title: Today in the Sky - USA TODAY
thread.title: Paying passengers now flying on United's new Boeing 777-300ER
thread.title_full: Paying passengers now flying on United's new Boeing 777-300ER

author: Ben Mutzabaugh , USA TODAY
title: Paying passengers now flying on United's new Boeing 777-300ER

text:
The flight crew aboard United's first revenue flight on the carrier's new Boeing 777-300ER pose for a picture prior to departing Newark Liberty airport on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2017. (Photo: United Airlines)
After a splashy public debut on Monday , United Airlines’ brand new Boeing 777-300ER flew paying passengers for the first time Thursday morning.
The new aircraft debuted on a 7 a.m. flight from Newark Liberty to San Francisco, with Flight 539 arriving to California about a half-hour ahead of schedule, according to United’s website. While United grabbed headlines with a special demonstration flight with the plane Monday , Thursday marked the aircraft's entry into regular scheduled service for the carrier.
The new 777-300ER is United’s first to include its new “Polaris” business-class seats, a revamp of premium seating that the carrier hopes will help it win back high-yield customers that it’s lost this decade to rivals like Delta and American.
The jet's new cabin features updated lie-flat seats and direct-aisle access for all passengers in the Polaris cabin. The economy cabin is updated too, though customers may find the 10-abreast, 3-4-3 layout to be a bit tight.
United will slowly incorporate its latest cabin update to across more of its long-haul fleet as it takes delivery of additional 777-300ER aircraft. The airline took delivery of its first model of the jet – the same one that flew Thursday’s flight – in December. United expects to add 13 more to its fleet this year.
United's new Boeing 777-300ER, Polaris cabin gets splashy debut flight

You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 47 2 of 47 3 of 47 4 of 47 5 of 47 6 of 47 7 of 47 8 of 47 9 of 47 10 of 47 11 of 47 12 of 47 13 of 47 14 of 47 15 of 47 16 of 47 17 of 47 18 of 47 19 of 47 20 of 47 21 of 47 22 of 47 23 of 47 24 of 47 25 of 47 26 of 47 27 of 47 28 of 47 29 of 47 30 of 47 31 of 47 32 of 47 33 of 47 34 of 47 35 of 47 36 of 47 37 of 47 38 of 47 39 of 47 40 of 47 41 of 47 42 of 47 43 of 47 44 of 47 45 of 47 46 of 47 47 of 47 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide To help speed the process, United also will begin retrofitting some of its current older Boeing 777-200s and Boeing 767s with the new cabin.
FlightGlobal.com reports that a combined 69 of those aircraft models are slated to get the retrofit. United “will begin modifications to the first of 14 767-300ERs in April and the first of 55 777-200s in the fourth quarter," the publication writes.
As for the new 777-300ERs, they’ll initially fly between Newark and San Francisco – a hub-to-hub route for United that connects two of its biggest bases and will allow crews to become familiar with the cabin layout on the new aircraft.
United will expand its 777-300ER service to international routes as more models of the plane enter its fleet. The airline says the new Polaris-outfitted planes will begin flying between San Francisco and Hong Kong on March 25 when the 777-300ER will replace United’s Boeing 747-400s that currently fly the route.
The fleet and hubs of United Airlines, by the numbers
